dataset.title: Stated Choice Experiment to measure willingness to pay for stream health improvements in Macon County, NC, 2012-2013

creator.organizationName: Coweeta Long Term Ecological Research Program

address.deliveryPoint: Daniel B. Warnell School of Forestry and Natural Resources

abstract.para: We ran a survey with a random sample of 3500 residents in Macon County, NC. We drew the sample from a total of 26993 parcels identified in the Macon County tax data. We ran the survey between September 2012 and February 2013 and had a response rate of 40.8%. The survey included a stated choice experiment designed to measure willingness to pay for stream health improvements in the region. The survey also included a set of auxiliary questions to assess general preferences for land management and relevant environmental characteristics.

section.title: CE analysis
section.para: Survey results were analyzed using a latent class logit model to estimate willingness to pay for stream health indicators under both proposed programs in the split sample design. We began with a basic conditional logit. Due to substantial heterogeneity of responses, we moved to examining a latent class logit conditioned on respondent characteristics reflected in the auxiliary questions. We chose the final model that had the best fit according to AIC and adjusted R2.

section.title: Choice experiment design
section.para: We consulted with ecologists, anthropologists, and geographers working in the Coweeta LTER to align the attributes of the CE with the Stream Visual Assessment Protocol. We tested the overall readability and relevance of the attribute in two focus groups. Because there was extensive resistence to goverment intervention in the region, we split the sample and tested for variation in the mechanisms of implementation for the hypothetical program that would target stream health improvement in the region. Using NGENE 1.1.1 we created a d-efficient experimental design with 20 choice scenarios blocked into 5 groups, resulting in 20 total versions of the survey.

section.title: Willingess to Pay estimates
section.para: We calculated WTP estimates and confidence intervals using the delta method of the Wald procedure in NLOGIT 5.0

section.title: Survey
section.para: A sampling frame of 26993 parcels was collected using Macon County tax data.
We drew a random sample of 3500 addresses from this sampling frame as recipients for the target survey.

abstract.para: Multi-scale process-oriented research is proposed on the consequences to the southernAppalachian socio-ecological system of the interaction between changing climate and landuse. Landscapes in the southeastern U.S. are expected to change profoundly in the next fivedecades as the socioeconomic factors driving the dramatic exurbanization of the past threedecades persist, and the changes to the rates, frequencies, and intensities of importantclimatic factors occur. Climate and land use change will especially impact the rural andquasi-rural lands that still characterize much of southern Appalachia where this research iscentered.The proposed research will extend long-term measurements, field experiments andinterdisciplinary modeling from small watershed studies to regional-scale analyses so as toaccount for increases in resource demand and competition from adjacent and more distantareas. The research focus will be on the provisioning service of water quantity, the regulatingservice of water quality, and the supporting service of maintaining biodiversity. Theoverarching question that guides this research is: How will key ecosystem processes and thefocal ecosystem services of water quantity, water quality, and biodiversity be impacted bythe: (1) transition in land uses from wildland to urban and peri-urban; (2) changes in climate;and (3) interactions between changes in land use and climate including both on-site and off-site feedbacks?

funding.para: This material is based upon work supported by the National Science Foundation under grant numbers DEB-0823293, DEB-9632854 and DEB-0218001. Any opinions, findings, conclusions, or recommendations expressed in the material are those of the author(s) and do not necessarily reflect the views of the National Science Foundation.

Quality control analysis was performed using the GCE Data Toolbox for MATLAB software. Column data types are validated upon importing the table into MATLAB, and qualifier flags are automatically generated for data values based on QA/QC criteria for each data column pre-defined in metadata templates (e.g. value range checks, sanity checks, pattern checks). Qualifier flags are also assigned to values that are imputed or derived, revised, or otherwise differ from values in the original data submission. A column of coded qualifier flags is generated and included in the data table if flags are assigned to any value in a data column.

ns2:unit.name: percent
ns2:unit.ns2:description: ratio of two quantities as percent composition (1:100)
